data.text: Dehydrated Food / Boil in the Bag Meals for Bike Touring
Hi Has anyone got suggestions for dehydrated food / boil in the bag to purchase prior to touring. I have googled some and the prices are considerable. Thanks in advance
Huel hot & savoury is my go to when I need food I can carry.
data.author: Pete Crossman

data.text: One vote for firepot meals.
data.author: Rob Skinner

data.text: ‚ÄòFood on the move‚Äô nice
data.author: Laura Togwell

data.text: Wayfarer do good meals
data.author: Allan Galloway

data.text: Summit to eat, firepot and adventure foods are all good. I try to buy them when there's a deal on. Lots of places selling online üëç
data.author: Gary Taylor

data.text: British army 24 hr ration packs .usually around a tenner but you get allot for your money.
data.author: Richard Bendall

data.text: non dairy whitener, coffee and tea and that gross long life chocolate are all fit for the bin... Not to mention the weird cardboard. I mean biscuits... I hope they've improved since the 90s....
data.author: Sigrid Identitee

data.text: As someone who used these packs you'll find they aren't particularly tasty, they certainly aren't light and they contain things you don't need. That is, unless you need a hammer. The Oatmeal biscuits make a good mallet. The American version is better... but you'll need a car to carry them.
data.author: Peter Jeynes

data.text: Buy a food dehydration machine and make your own .
data.author: Gary Slater

data.text: Search marketplace for huel. People are always selling the hot meals.. they are no worse than anything else taste wise, plus less waste because it's in one bag not individuals. Also, they are nutritionally superior to lots of others. You can add bits to them if you want to, but not necessary.
data.author: Sigrid Identitee

data.text: If you are going through places with shops buy fresh as you go and cook on the way. On the other hand you can dehydrate your own food in a dehydrator. They aren't desperately expensive
data.author: Peter Jeynes

data.text: Check out the instant dried pasta meals/rice meals at most supermarkets. Also "Bean feast" brand dried food, padded out with dried cous cous or bulgur wheat. Also, look on ebay for British forces 24hr ration packs (you will have to inbox them and re-pack them for panniers).
data.author: Mark Severs

data.text: Check out 'Look what we found', I think some Waitrose stores stock them, also on Amazon. Not camping specific but I've used them for years.
data.author: Mark Grant

data.text: I‚Äôd forgotten the name of these. They used to sell them in Morrisons. Thanks for jogging the memory
data.author: Matt Hill

data.text: Huel Mac & Cheese is a winner for me.
data.author: Claire V Gan

data.text: I prefer the huel Cajun pasta
data.author: Martyn Downing

data.text: not tried that yet. I might have to give that a go ta
data.author: Claire V Gan

data.text:
Summit to eat. Not too outlandishly expensive. Tasty enough. There‚Äôs some niche stuff on https://basecampfood.com Also just started using pouched food company on eBay. Only had the choc pudding so far but it was nice
Base Camp Food: lightweight, expedition freeze dried meals and stoves
basecampfood.com
data.author: Matt Hill

data.text: I tend to use the local pub! But find wayfarer palatable. Porridge sachets for breakfast and coffee bags!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: Used summit to eat last year . Mac n cheese, tikka and beef n potato all very good . Bel vita biscuits for brekkie .
data.author: Ian Livingston

data.text: Look what we found meals are my preference.
data.author: Mark Steel

data.text: Thank you üôè everyone. Some great ideas
data.author: Gary Allen

data.text: These are great, knorr do 4 different recipes, You only need water, I don't bother with the expensive meals anymore, these are perfect to add extras into.
data.author: Ian Mort

data.text: Another vote for the Firepot meals. Good selection of dishes and they do gluten free options too üëçüèº
data.author: Neil Johnson

data.text: Firepot
data.author: Mike French

data.text: Uncle Ben savoury rice. Various options/flavours. Relatively cheap. Very quick and easy to prepare. Only requires about three tablespoons of boiling water so easy on stove fuel. Widely available at supermarkets UK and Europe
data.author: Peter Robertson

data.text: Checkout Bijou Thomas and Alan Lim's advice on dehydrated food. It's likely to cause some severe gastro intestinal stress ;-)
data.author: Liam Henry Hallam

data.text: For breakfast preweighed amount of porridge oats with dried milk powder just add water and bring to the simmer cheap as chips
data.author: Les Parsons

data.text: Dried mashed potatoes or polenta. Add textured vegetable protein/jerky/dried meat/cheese for protein and dried veggies. Add herbs and spices to taste. Cheap and easy to find
data.author: Dermot Blackweir

data.text: Expedition Food . 1000 calories / bag . ¬£7. 99 ( double portion ) bought from Base camp Food . We got free deliver because we have Amazon prime.
data.author: Peter Couttie

data.text: Tbh things like pot noodles give you around the best calorie to buck ratio. You can take them out of the pots and put them in bags for space saving. Instant noodles from a Chinese store are nice too. I do like things like expedition foods, especially at the end of a day. I find I like to be carb heavy when I'm riding and have taken to rehydrating noodles with cold water (yeah I know, gross right?), then stopping for something more fatty like spaghetti carbonara as the sun sets.
data.author: Ed Fraser

data.text: that‚Äôs what we do üëå
data.author: Chris Pickering

data.text: I did the surplus army ration packs. Those were good, came with some water purifying tablets too and other goodies
data.author: Magnus Eric Olafsson

data.text: I am new to this so thanks everyone for sharing your food experiences
data.author: Tony Bevan

data.text: Great British porridge company is a good instant porridge for breakfast. Just add boiling water.
data.author: Sarah Woodcock

data.text: Are you going to be carrying food for the entire trip? I just use what ever is available in the local shops an pubs
data.author: David Kitson

data.text: we will visit shops and pubs, but also need to have something in reserve
data.author: Gary Allen

data.text: I'd just look in the supermarket at the noodles and pasta isle. Usually something very cheap. Most taste like crap imo but as a backup and maybe a portion of Rego to make a recovery drink plus a few cereal bars you can make do
data.author: David Kitson
